A very solid trading statement from boohoo with sales and gross margin ahead of expectations. The company's updated guidance implies adj EBITDA of c.£80m for the year which is in-line with current consensus so this statement is unlikely to drive much change to consensus but the implied growth of +32% in 4Q looks conservative relative to +47% growth ytd. The £189m cash balance highlights the optionality in this business.

FATDAZ @soundbuy re Bohoo yes I did
11:20 am
BE11:20am

Implications — FY19e underlying EBITDA £80m retained — This results statement is consistent with our underlying FY19e EBITDA forecast of £80m, (EPS 3.69p, +19.2% yoy), based on 2H sales growth of +45.4%, GM +130bps and EBIT margins -130bps yoy. Underlying PBT excludes £7.5m of exceptional costs related to the dual running of distribution centres.
 Investment case — boohoo combines a highly efficient product design, sourcing and merchandising platform with an opportunity to significantly grow its sales base both in the UK and Internationally. However, on an ambitious forecast agenda, boohoo shares are trading at a significant premium to peers. We see this premium as a limit to upside on a 12 month view and therefore assign a Neutral rating

BE11:20am

And Barclays.

PBateman is pat val still suspended?
Soundbuy That's two of us then......... :)
BE11:21am

Given the pain that has been felt elsewhere through peak trading, Boohoo’s ability to deliver a small revenue beat at a decent gross margin, as well as a small guidance upgrade, is pretty impressive. However, we think expectations heading into this statement had risen after the company put out a comment in mid-December saying they were “trading comfortably in line with market expectations” and a strong share price performance in the last couple of weeks. The guidance uplift doesn’t point to any upgrade to consensus. And although PLT has again been very strong, bears have something to run with: Boohoo hasn’t seen growth accelerate from 1H despite a markedly easier comp. So although this statement definitely justifies a large outperformance vs ecommerce in recent weeks, it doesn’t necessarily give a big further positive injection.

We are Equal Weight. Valuation is expensive on EV/Sales (2.3x vs ASOS on 0.8x) and EV/EBITDA (24x vs ASOS on 15x) but not on P/E (Boohoo’s 38x a discount to ASOS 46x). That reflects big differences in capital intensity between the businesses. But we do see the gap in ROIC in our ASOS model (8%) vs our Boohoo model (greater than 50%) as unsustainable long term, if not quickly reversible near term. We see more value in ASOS here, if not necessarily earnings momentum.

Tom Dalgleish at least a month past due when the final report was mooted

But here's where it gets complicated. If it's related to the Wire Act, the ruling might really just relate to cross border.

BE11:28am

Here's Barclays.

Cash man #meaningful votes Ayes 250
11:28 am
BE11:29am

We note that we value the US sports betting business of PPB to be worth £2 a share, we value GVC’s US sports betting business to be worth c. 99p a share, we value WMH US to be worth 54p a share and we value The Stars group’s US sports betting business to be worth $2 a share. However, we value these US sports businesses by focusing on the potential cash flows from sports betting, not online gaming (that is a potential upside to valuation) and given we do not think this ruling applies to sports betting, share price weakness should present a buying opportunity. We note the Department of Justice’s ruling appears to be related to the Wire Act applying to online gaming and suggests to us that cross-state gaming (e.g. cross state pooling of poker liquidity may be under pressure which is clearly bad for online gaming focused operators) but we don’t see (at this time) how this materially impacts US sports betting as the Wire Act already applies to product. Broadly, we think this is possibly worst news for The Stars Group out of the four companies we cover given the company’s exposure to online gaming but even then we do not view it as necessarily material.

Flaneur #meaningfulvote - mumble, mumble, something about Putin, hacking, Trump hamburgers etc...I agree with @ML - there is no solution to this, no end.
PBateman see you all in the Red Lion at 7
Electric Dragon PBateman - Supremacy Clause of Art. VI - federal law is the supreme law of the land and overrides state law. Doctrine of pre-emption applies.
DJ weren't sports betting (not online) laws recently relaxed in the US?
Shinshin @PB No clear cut answer, states can do things banned federally, various ruling s on constituionality would be needed. Source: my dimly remembered US govt courses
BE11:30am

The key here is that the Wire Act is already applicable to sports

BE11:30am

Meaning ........ zero impact? Maybe?

Electric Dragon https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_preemption

PBateman so how long can the NJ online casinos run for?
BE11:31am

The Wire Act applies to transactions across state borders. On its face it therefore would not apply to gambling within a state. However, it is hard to keep every aspect of Internet gambling within a state; notably, payment processing transactions. The Internet is not designed to stop at borders.

PBateman Until there's litigation?
A. M. I thought that there was a move to allow online gambling in the US at some point last year.
BE11:31am

Until 2011 the 1961 Wire Act was held to apply to all gambling. In 2011 the DoJ issued an opinion that held that it only applied to sports betting. States permitted the launch of online casino and poker partly as a result of confidence that activities within the state would not offend federal law.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Oh, and to add to the confusion, Government websites aren't being updated due to the shutdown so no one seems to be able to find the actual ruling .....

BE11:32am

The best guess is:

BE11:32am

We believe issues may arise for:
• Payment processing. Already a challenge for US online gambling, payment services may be withdrawn, cost more or become more difficult for the player to use.
• Daily Fantasy Sports. DFS partly operates across state borders. It may be licensed in some states, but the prize pools are shared we believe. There are different views about whether DFS is sports betting and this interpretation could become more important if the DoJ or others decide to test it in court.
• Inter-state poker. Nevada, Delaware and New Jersey are pooling poker liquidity, which could be put in doubt by this new DoJ ruling

Liberty bid for Millicom shaken out by Reuters late yesterday.

11:41 am

Via Liberty Latin America, which is half the size of Millicom but is obviously a Liberty vehicle so has bottomless access to debt.

BE11:42am

Rumour of this one was going around for ages ......

BE11:42am

Quick line from Olivetree to explain the logic:

11:42 am
BE11:42am

With compelling strategic rationale, clear potential for value creation, scope for supportive target shareholders and Liberty’s appetite for creative financing structures, this is a story which could well end up coming to fruition. The assets of both companies are broadly complimentary in nature but overlaps in Panama and Costa Rica will likely need to be addressed. Milllicom currently trades at a c40% discount to Liberty paper and at 1x is underlevered vs Liberty’s c5x. This seemingly provides opportunity for a classic Malone structure, using the target’s own balance sheet to take advantage of the valuation discrepancy between the two shares. It would seem the main question here would what Kinnevik’s stance would be towards receipt of non-voting Liberty shares.

The current state of play is clearly very early stage, but the companies and managements know each other very well indeed. It is entirely possible to understand the underlying strategic rationale for the deal, and employing the “usual” style of financial engineering employed by Malone vehicles makes it reasonably straightforward to get the mathematics to work. The main question would seem to be whether Liberty are able to generate a structure which combines both a valuation and stock/cash mix sufficient to win the support of Kinnevik. The latter has been happy to talk of stated goals of diversification though and has a history of maximising shareholder value through supporting strategic transactions where possible. Although early, there would appear to be plenty of scope for this story to firm up in the coming weeks.

Not Your Business #meaningfulvote 212

11:53 am
BE11:53am

The slight miss to guidance, which had been slashed in September, and to consensus, which had been cut twice in the year, will not be taken well by the market, although the modest scale of the miss indicates that another substantial fall in the shares is unlikely, in our view.
● Guidance for 2019 will be published at the time of the company’s financial results, on 28 February, but in our view it will take at least one reporting period without downgrades for the stock to demonstrate some strength, and in the meantime we suspect that there is more downside to forecasts than upside.
● Industry data hiatus. We had previously relied on weekly e-referral data as a two to threemonth
forecast of NHS activity at Spire hospitals, although changing patient mix had begun to make this less a less useful tool. Now, the NHS appears to have paused publication of this data, further limiting our insight into the market. However, we have seen little evidence that demand in picking up.
● We apply a 7-8x EBITDA multiple to a bear case £122m-125m EBITDA in 2019, resulting in a 104-141p/share fair value range; we use the middle of the range for our 120p/share price target.

BE11:54am

Note also that Spire was up 7% or so going into figures, for no obvious reason.

Finlay More companies are doing the dance of the seven veils in their trading statements.
BE11:55am

Morgan Stanley remain positive, partly on the Long Term Plan. Which, um, yeah, okay .....

A. M. @Finlay "Our Purpose is to build the digital highways that connect people, improve lives and develop communities." -- more than seven, surely.
11:55 am
BE11:55am

While the result implies a slight downgrade to the base EBITDA (-3-4%), the reduction in net debt does alleviate concerns of a covenant breach. We believe that 2019 guidance given at the full earnings release on February 28 will be a more significant catalyst for the shares and that this will be an upside risk event. We think sentiment is negative in anticipation of the NHS business continuing to decline materially; if Spire can demonstrate stability in sales growth and margins,
the shares should be rewarded. Following the publication of the NHS Long Term Plan on January 7, which included commitments on cutting waiting times for elective care, emphasised patient choice and recommended use of the independent sector capacity, Spire's NHS business may see support from the weak levels seen in 2018. Furthermore, the January 10 2019/20 Planning Guidance indicates that fines will be applied for providers where patients are waiting more than 52 weeks for treatment, further accelerating the need for elective care waiting lists to decrease, which could benefit Spire volumes.

Vanquis: Q4 account bookings were 76,000, 17,000 lower than Q4 2017, Total bookings for 2018, at 366,000, were 71,000 lower than 2017 reflecting the end of the Argos contract, tighter underwriting and a 'temporary' reduction in the marketing program in Q4 as a new underwriting platform went live. Year-end customer numbers rose 3.1% YoY to 1.77m which is behind our 1.85m target. Receivables grew by 5% against our 8%-9% average receivables growth forecast. CCMS measures on persistent debt are likely to moderate growth in 2019. There has been some pressure on delinquency and arrears metrics in H2, reflecting the increased use of payment arrangements. Underwriting, however, has been progressively tightened over the last 18 months. The risk-adjusted margin has shown a further reduction in Q4.

At Q3 we noted that profitability had been pushed to the right in CCD. We believe the market will be disappointed that Q4 shows a further drift down in profitability, this time from the impairment charge at Vanquis. PFG currently trades at a consensus 2019 PE of 12.9x
